WRITING.TEXT: The great Johannes Grtzke left us yesterday, aged 79.

WRITING.TITLE: "Komm, setz dich zu uns" ("Sit down and join us") by Johannes Grtzke, oil on canvas, 1970

WRITING.TEXT: According to hearsay any Hungarians around to confirm this? , in Hungarian the definite insult is to send someone back into their mother.

If you had asked me about him yesterday I'd have called him the greatest living German painter. A probably representative gallery of paintings by him can be found behind the link, where an ongoing exhibition in the Netherlands is advertised.

WRITING.TITLE: Sadly I have to tell you that today Johannnes Grtzke has died.

WRITING.TEXT: Yes: In Mnster we have 1.6 bicycles per person. And we need them.
Shortly after he finished this work, the painter was shot by a Republican commando in the Spanish Civil War, as were his father and brother one day later.

WRITING.TITLE: Self portrait, Alfonso Ponce de Len, oil on canvas, 1936

WRITING.TEXT: This is amazing in its sheer brazen improbability :D Care to tell me where it hangs?

I'll post some fun stuff from my "seen" collection (I use to take notes on each of my museum visits and make sure to collect decent-quality scans of those picks typically about 2 to 10) over the next days. This is from one of the leading East German painters, the late Werner Tbke.
Historical context: Dr. Schulze is a (fictitious) Nazi jurist, an allegory of the continuity in personnel from the Nazi time into the West German Federal Republic (the East had some of those cases, but significantly fewer, and used the Western examples for propaganda). The best-known such ex-Nazi officials were Hans Globke, in fact a jurist, who was the second-most influential West German statesman after chancellor Adenauer in the 1950s and who in 1935 had drafted the most prominent commentary to the Nuremberg laws; and Theodor Oberlnder, minister for refugees and expulsed people and formerly probably engaged in the massacres of Lww, amongst other murderous activities.

WRITING.TITLE: "Memoirs of Dr. iur. Schulze II", Werner Tbke, oil on canvas, 1965

WRITING.TEXT: I wonder whether you can use the colour for paper marbling.
